advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, the micro capital"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"> Our Peripheral Expansion System gives you plug-in cards for memory expansion, P-Code capabilities, a disk drive controler and the RS-232 interface. You can also add a modem, speech synthetiser, disk drive and matrix printer...<br><br> ... TI BASIC is built into the computer, but it can also handle TI Extended BASIC, UCSD Pascal, TI LOGO, TMS-9900 Assembly language and TI PILOT ... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 6</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The facts speak for themselves. The QUAY 500 SERIES offers more for the money than North Star Horizon computers...<br><br> ...The bottom line is simple. There is a new star in the computer field. The 500 SERIES by Quay. It outshines all of the competition.<br><br></font> A little pretentious tone!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.sapere.demon.co.uk/computers/honeywell.html" target="_blank">Adrian Wise's website</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A complete system, including furniture (except chair) for only A$13164.95" Ouch!! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATH CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract from the 1961 Heathkit catalog</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil is an awesome manager"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"After the compliments made to the Amstrad CPC-464, what could be added ?"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983 - The real-size system picture occupied almost the full right page. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - It was the time when one still lacked good programs for the IBM PC...<br><br> Advert said: <font color="#666666"><br><br> Attention, all programmers. Here's a chance to reach the top.<br> If you've written software that's completed and runs on the IBM Personal Computer (or another computer), we could be interested in publishing it...<br> ... We select programs that will make the IBM Personal Computer an even more useful toll for modern times...</font></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Athena used the NSC 800 microprocessor which was a low consumption version of the Zilog Z80.
The computer had a battery which allowed it to be used for two hours or six hours in "awake" state.
Apparently it was the first "clamshell" laptop computer to be exhibited, but never went into production. It was designed by David Mitchell.
computer.name: ATHENA
